      • getIntersection

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getIntersection​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> a,
                                                                     java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> b)
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -
        Returns:
        items that occur in both the lists. the order of items in the reversed list should be in the order they occur in the first list. also, there should be a single instance of each item in the resulting list. For example: a = [1,4,3,6,2,1,2,7,3,2,8,7,7] b = [7,7,7,7,4,4,5,5,5,5,1,1,1,7,1,1,1,1,1,2] return [1,4,2,7] return null if either list is null

      • getIntersectionV2

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getIntersectionV2​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> a,
                                                                       java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> b)
        a modified version of getIntersection
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -
        Returns:
        items that occur in both the lists. the order of items in the reversed list should be in the order they occur in the first list. the number of times an item exists in the resulting list is the smaller of the occurrences of that item in a and b For example: a = [1,4,3,6,2,1,2,7,3,2,8,7,7] b = [4,4,5,5,5,5,1,1,1,7,1,1,1,1,1,2,7] return [1,4,2,1,7,7] return null if either list is null

      • itemsInAtleastN

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> itemsInAtleastN​(java.util.ArrayList<java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer>> list,
                                                                     int n)
        Parameters:
        list - : an ArrayList of ArrayLists
        n - : assume n is more than 0
        Returns:
        a list containing items that exist in at least n (sub)ArrayList of the passed list order of items should be - all items from the first sub-list that satisfy the requirement, followed by, all items from the second sub-list (but not in the first sub-list) that satisfy the requirement, followed by, all items from the third sub-list (but not in the first two sub-lists) that satisfy the requirement, and so on... for example, if list = [[1,2,3,4,5], [4,6,7,8], [3,5,7,6]] and n = 2, return the list [3,4,5,6,7] if list = [[1,2,3,4,5], [4,6,7,8], [3,5,7,6]] and n = 3, return the list [] if list = [[1,2,3,4,5,6], [4,6,7,8], [3,5,7,6,4]] and n = 3, return the list [4, 6]

      • productAllButOne

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> productAllButOne​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list)
        from GeeksForGeeks.com return an list (say prod) such that for all i, prod.get(i) is equal to the product of all the elements of list except list.get(i). IMPORTANT!!! Solve it without division operator and in O(n). Example : if list = {10, 3, 5, 6, 2} then prod = {180, 600, 360, 300, 900}
        Parameters:
        list -
        Returns:
        list based on above specs

      • getLongestConsecutiveLength

        public static int getLongestConsecutiveLength​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list)
        Parameters:
        list -
        Returns:
        length of the longest collection of consecutive items (in terms of value, not order) For example, if list = {0, 10, 3, -2, 5, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 2, 1, 12, -1}, the longest collection of consecutive values is -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 (6 items in total). so return 6.

      • getLongestAscendingSequence

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getLongestAscendingSequence​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list)
        Parameters:
        list -
        Returns:
        the longest sequence in ascending order. return the sequence that occurs first in case of a tie. for example, if list = {10, 70, 20, 50, 50, 80}, return {20, 50, 50, 80} if list = {70, 70, 20, 10, 80, 20}, return {70, 70} if list = {50, 40, 30, 30}, return {30} if list = null, return null if list = {}, return {}

      • getLongestDescendingSequence

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getLongestDescendingSequence​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list)
        Parameters:
        list -
        Returns:
        the longest sequence in descending order. return the sequence that occurs first in case of a tie. for example, if list = {10, 70, 50, 20, 10, 50, 50, 80}, return {70, 50, 20, 10} if list = {70, 70, 90, 10, 90, 80}, return {70, 70} if list = {50, 40, 30, 30}, return {50, 40, 30, 30} if list = null, return null if list = {}, return {}

      • getLongestUnchangedSequence

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getLongestUnchangedSequence​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list)
        Parameters:
        list -
        Returns:
        the longest sequence of the same item. return the sequence that occurs first in case of a tie. for example, if list = {10, 30, 30, 30, 30, 50, 50, 80}, return {30, 30, 30, 30} if list = {70, 70, 90, 90, 80, 80}, return {70, 70} if list = {50, 40, 30, 20}, return {50} if list = null, return null if list = {}, return {}

        Parameters:

      • sortIfNeeded

        public static void sortIfNeeded​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list,
                                boolean asc)
        Parameters:
        list -
        asc - if the list is already sorted (either ascending or descending), do nothing regardless of asc, otherwise sort the list in ascending order if asc is true, otherwise sort the list in descending order

      • reverseSort

        public static void reverseSort​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list)
        Parameters:
        list - if the list is in ascending order, sort it in descending order if the list is in descending order, sort it in ascending order do nothing if the list is unsorted

      • getCommonItemsSorted

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getCommonItemsSorted​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> a,
                                                                          java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> b)
        Parameters:
        a - : sorted in ascending order
        b - : sorted in ascending order
        Returns:
        an list containing the common items from a and b. If list a contains p occurrences of an item and list b contains q occurrences of the same item, the list returned must have Math.min(p, q) occurrences of that item.

      • getCommonItemsUnsorted

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getCommonItemsUnsorted​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> a,
                                                                            java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> b)
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -
        Returns:
        an list containing the common items from a and b. If list a contains p occurrences of an item and list b contains q occurrences of the same item, the list returned must have Math.min(p, q) occurrences of that item. All occurrences of an item in the resulting list should be together, and be in the order of first appearance in list a. See the last junit test sample for details

      • noCommonItems

        public static boolean noCommonItems​(java.util.ArrayList<java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer>> list)
        Parameters:
        list -
        Returns:
        true if there are no common items between any two sublists of the list passed, false otherwise.

      • longestMirroredSequence

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> longestMirroredSequence​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list)
        Parameters:
        list -
        Returns:
        the longest sequence of items that occurs in the mirrored (back to front) form as well. in case of a tie, return the sequence that occurs first. Examples: if list = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 20, 10, 40, 30, 20, 50, 40} return the list {20, 30, 40} (not {40, 30, 20}) if list = {1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2} return the list {1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2,1} if list = {5,6,7,8,9} return the list {5} if list = {5,6,7,5,7,6,8,5,6,9} return the list {6,7}

      • getSet

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getSet​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> list)
        in math, a "set" is defined as a collection of **distinct** items. Thus, [1,7,2,9] is a set, but [1,7,2,1,9] is not (since 1 occurs multiple times).
        Parameters:
        list -
        Returns:
        a "set" obtained from the passed array. the order of the items should be the order in of the first occurrences of the items in the passed array. for example, if list = [1,7,2,1,9,7,9,9], return [1,7,2,9] if list = [7,2,1,1,9,7,9,9], return [7,2,1,9]
